title: Opinion: Jets made right move by trading Leonard Williams to Giants
text:
CLOSE What I’m Hearing: Jet’s young QB Sam Darnold says these last two games have been the worst of his life. USA TODAY

No one was surprised Monday when the New York Jets traded Leonard Williams.

The destination? Well, that was a bit of a shocker.

Williams is headed to the New York Giants.

According to ESPN, it’s the first time the cross-town rivals have ever made a trade. And it is a big one.

Williams has been one of the biggest faces of the Jets’ defense for the last four-plus years. And while his production never lived up to his draft pick — the No. 6 overall selection in 2016 with just 17 sacks in 71 career games — he was respected by his teammates, coaches and opponents for impacting the game in ways that don’t show up on the stat sheet.

It’s also a symbolic move. It’s the first major transaction by Jets general manager Joe Douglas, and with it, he moved on from former GM Mike Maccagnan’s first-ever draft pick. Remarkably, none of the seven players from that 2015 Maccagnan draft remain on the team.

This is a new start for the Jets. And this was a good deal. Here’s why:

Why it makes sense

Anyone who has watched the Jets this season knows they have massive holes all over their roster. Douglas needs ammo to fill those holes, both long-term and short-term. So this was a deal that had to get done.

According to multiple reports, the Jets are getting the Giants’ third-round pick in 2020 and a 2021 fifth-round pick. ESPN reports that the fifth-round pick could become a fourth-round pick if Williams signs an extension with the Giants before the start of the new league year and that the Jets picked up $4 million of Williams’ remaining $6 million salary this year.

New York Jets defensive end Leonard Williams (92) celebrates during the second half against the Buffalo Bills at MetLife Stadium. (Photo: Vincent Carchietta, USA TODAY Sports)

Those two picks, if Douglas gets them right, could go a long way toward rebuilding the offensive line, or finding a big-play receiver, or landing a pass rusher. And while losing Williams hurts the defense, the Jets’ defensive line is their deepest position group on the roster.

They already had nearly $16 million of their cap in 2020 committed to Quinnen Williams and Henry Anderson, and some young lineman who have shown potential, including Kyle Phillips, Folorunso Fatukasi and Jordan Willis.

Even if the Jets were good, it wouldn’t have made a ton of sense to keep Williams and pay him big money. But with their massive struggles, trading him was a no-brainer.

And the Giants provided a package that gave the Jets the market value they needed. A year ago, the Rams sent a third- and a fifth-round pick to the Jaguars for Dante Fowler, Jr.

Blow to the locker room

The dejection in the Jets' locker room was palpable after they fell to 1-6 on Sunday in Jacksonville. Jamal Adams was as downtrodden as he's ever been after a loss.

"We're 1-6, man," said Adams, who is 10-29 in two-plus seasons with the Jets. "It’s been three years. It’s frustrating. I just want to win."

Dealing Williams isn't going to help. There is no argument for this deal making the Jets better in the short-term. It doesn't. And that's going to be a big blow for a prideful group of players who are already frustrated after losing seven of their first eight games -- and for many of them who were here last year, 15 out of their last 17.

Even before Williams was traded, Adam Gase was going to have a tough job keeping the locker room together. This move was necessary, but it won't make things any easier.

Major intrigue

It's a heck of a time for the first-ever trade between these two franchises: The Jets play the Giants next weekend. And the prospect of Williams going up against his former team makes an already-intriguing game between these two struggling teams that much more irresistible.

Can Williams use his knowledge against the Jets' horrible offensive line to have a breakout game? Will he notch his first sacks of the season against Sam Darnold? And now the Jets have extra incentive to beat the Giants because the worse their record the better the Jets' draft pick is in 2020.

It's always fun when these two teams play. But this game just got even more juice.
description: No one was surprised when the Jets traded Leonard Williams. The destination, though, was a bit of a shocker. But it was the right move for the Jets.
